thread.title: Tottenham 4-3 Wycombe: Heung-min Son saves Spurs from FA Cup shock - 5 things we learned
thread.title_full: Tottenham 4-3 Wycombe: Heung-min Son saves Spurs from FA Cup shock - 5 things we learned

author: Mike Walters
title: Tottenham 4-3 Wycombe: Heung-min Son saves Spurs from FA Cup shock - 5 things we learned
text:
Son saved Tottenham's blushes with the latest of winners (Photo: REUTERS)   Thank you for subscribing!   
Wonderful Wycombe produced a sensational performance to cut Tottenham 's strolling millionaires down to size at White Hart Lane. 
It took a 97 minute winner from Heung-min Son to rob the Chairboys of the replay they deserved. 
All six minutes of stoppage time signalled by referee Roger East had expired when Son prodded an undeserved winner into the roof of the net. 
Wycombe manager Gareth Ainsworth stood with his head in his hands on the touchline, scarcely unable to believe the injustice – and even the most blinkered Spurs fan could not blame him. 
England star Dele Alli's 89th minute equaliser was harsh enough on the Chairboys. But the climax was more cruel than vivisection. View gallery 
Two goals from skipper Paul Hayes and a soaring header from sub Garry Thompson gave Spurs all the headaches they could handle. 
Spurs players had warmed up in No.8 shirts bearing the legend 'Get Well Soon Ryan' as a tribute to their former team-mate Ryan Mason, who remains in hospital after suffering a fractured skull in Hull's 2-0 defeat at Chelsea last weekend. 
But after being led out by manager Gareth Ainsworth's son, Kane, as mascot, Wycombe led Tottenham a merry dance from the first minute as Adebayo Akinfenwa headed Sido Jombati's deep cross back across goal and Chairboys skipper Paul Hayes headed against the bar when he should have scored. 
Son's radar was also on the blink as he dragged wide of an open goal for the home side, and midway through the first half it became an expensive miss. 
Joe Jacobson's right-wing corner reached the far post and Hayes atoned for his earlier miss with a sublime left-foot volley beyond Michel Vorm. Dele Alli struck late to deny the Chairboys (Photo: REUTERS) 
And Wycombe were in dreamland nine minutes before the break as Sam Wood was brought down by a naïve challenge from Cameron Carter-Vickers and Hayes doubled their money from the penalty spot. 
It should have been 3-0 within a minute, only for Akinfenwa to head wide from six yards, and Spurs – unbeaten at the Lane this season - were booed off at the interval by a disbelieving crowd. 
Inevitably, Spurs boss Mauricio Pochettino sent in the cavalry, and two goals in four minutes restored business as usual. 
First Son's deflected shot beat Jamal Blackman at his near post to reduce the deficit after an hour, which was the cue for Poch Spice to send on midfield aristocrats Dele Alli and Mousa Dembele. 
And when Aaron Pierre checked half-time sub Vincent Janssen in the box, the Dutchman picked himself up to level the tie confidently from the spot. 
But what a fabulous performance from the Chairboys. In the very best of Cup traditions, they took Spurs to the wire. Garry Thompson thought he'd won it for Wycombe before Alli's equaliser (Photo: REUTERS) 
Here are five things we learned: 1. Sissoko stuck on autopilot 
There is a world of difference between a European Championship final and thankless Cup assignments when you're on a hiding to nothing. 
Moussa Sissoko might have looked a £30 million player when he raised his game for France last summer, but on this evidence you can see why Mauricio Pochettino has been unable to trust his big-money summer signing. 
Just as he went missing too often for Newcastle as the Toon slipped through the relegation hatch last season, Sissoko was a strolling aristocrat for 45 minutes as Wycombe threatened to bridge the 70-place gap between the teams. Moussa Sissoko failed to impress (Photo: REUTERS) 2. Janssen in the dark 
Now Vincent Janssen can't even get in the starting line-up when League Two minnows come calling at White Hart Lane. 
It would be fair to say Janssen's Tottenham career has not yet taken off. In fact, it has not even left the departure gate, let alone the runway. 
If manager Mauricio Pochettino was sending Harry Kane's £18 million understudy a coded message among his nine changes from the side who salvaged a 2-2 draw at Manchester City, it was surely along the lines of: Now, where did I put the receipt? 
But Poch Spice had seen enough, after 45 minutes of remarkable complacency, to send for the Dutchman in place of Georges-Kevin Nkoudou, and his fourth penalty of the season made it 2-2 as Tottenham fought back after a slipshod first half. Janssen scored from the spot (Photo: AFP) 3. Akinfenwa is an absolute best 
For all the cheap shots about his 16st frame and, ahem, physical attributes, Adebayo Akinfenwa has scored 169 goals in his career for a reason. 
The 'Beast' was never going to tiptoe around White Hart Lane and exit the Cup with a whimper if he could enjoy a good stomp, and England star Eric Dier didn't need a warning klaxon to know when Akinfenwa was around. 
It was the Beast whose header set up a glorious chance for his captain Paul Hayes in the first minute and, as ever, if Wycombe were looking for a target man, they could hardly miss him. Adebayo Akinfenwa gave Tottenham all they could handle (Photo: Dan Istitene) 4. Spurs home before the postcards 
Tottenham's four-day warm-weather training camp in Barcelona almost backfired on them. 
There is plenty of evidence on film to show Spurs pulled their weight in the 1992 Olympic stadium after Mauricio Pochettino decided to escape the grey chill of an English winter – nice work if you can get it – but his much-changed side played for 45 minutes as if they had not finished writing their postcards. Tottenham's warm weather training didn't pay off (Photo: Harry Kane / Instagram) 5. Ainsworth destined for bigger job 
On the day his son was a mascot, Gareth Ainsworth went through one of his most memorable 90 minutes as a manager. 
Wycombe were 25 seconds from promotion two years ago until Southend's stoppage-time equaliser in the League Two play-off final at Wembley took the game to penalties, where the Shrimpers prevailed. 
But Ainsworth has worked miracles on a pauper's budget at Adams Park, and surely there has to be a job higher up the scale for a manager who plays in a band called Dog Chewed The Handle. poll loading Will Tottenham win a trophy this season? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
